quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 11 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 11.9: Multiplying/Dividing Complex Numbers
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Operations on complex numbers in polar form

questions.question: If you multiply $z_1 = 2(\cos 30^{\circ} + i \sin 30^{\circ})$ and $z_2 = 5(\cos 40^{\circ} + i \sin 40^{\circ})$, what is the new modulus?
questions.explanation: To multiply complex numbers in trig form, multiply the moduli: 2 * 5 = 10.

questions.question: Using the same $z_1$ and $z_2$ from above, what is the argument of the product $z_1z_2$?
questions.explanation: To multiply complex numbers in trig form, add the angles: 30° + 40° = 70°.

questions.question: Divide $z_1 = 12(\cos 150^{\circ} + i \sin 150^{\circ})$ by $z_2 = 3(\cos 50^{\circ} + i \sin 50^{\circ})$.
questions.explanation: Divide the moduli (12 / 3 = 4) and subtract the angles (150° - 50° = 100°).

questions.question: If the result of a division gives an angle of $-20^{\circ}$, what is the standard positive argument?
questions.explanation: Angles are coterminal. Adding 360° to -20° gives the positive equivalent of 340°.

questions.question: True or False: To multiply $z$ by itself ($z^2$), you square the modulus and double the angle.
questions.explanation: True. Based on the multiplication rule: r * r = r² and θ + θ = 2θ.

questions.question: What is the modulus of the quotient if you divide a number by itself ($z/z$)?
questions.explanation: r / r = 1. This matches the logic that any number divided by itself is 1.

questions.question: What happens to the angle if you divide $z$ by its conjugate $\bar{z}$? (Note: Conjugate angle is $-\theta$)
questions.explanation: θ - (-θ) = 2θ. The resulting angle is twice the original.

questions.question: Division in trig form is related to which algebraic process in standard form?
questions.explanation: Dividing $a+bi$ by $c+di$ requires multiplying the top and bottom by the conjugate of the denominator; the trig form bypasses this tedious step.

questions.question: If $z_1$ has $r=1$, what is the modulus of $z_1 z_2$?
options: The same as the modulus of z₂.
questions.explanation: 1 * r₂ = r₂. Multiplying by a complex number with a modulus of 1 only changes the direction (angle), not the length.

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You've found the 'shortcut' to complex operations.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Just remember: Multiply radii/Add angles, Divide radii/Subtract angles.
scoreMessages.50: Be careful with your arithmetic when adding or subtracting fractions (radians).
scoreMessages.0: Review the product and quotient rules for complex numbers in polar form.
